newsitem.title: INDIA: India RBI not seen enforcing risk cover.
newsitem.headline: India RBI not seen enforcing risk cover.

text.p: Top officials of the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) on Saturday indicated they were not in favour of mandatory hedging of external commercial borrowings (ECBs) by Indian firms.

Several leading bankers and foreign exchange brokers at an annual meeting of Forex Association of India had earlier said that firms must be told to compulsorily cover at least 25-50 percent of their ECBs.
Such a step would create demand for forward dollars, they said.
"Exchange markets are there to cover risks," a senior RBI official told the meeting. "Risk cover should never come by fiat. It is a wrong expectation of the central bank."
Indian firms have been raising ECBs taking advantage of cheaper offshore funds, but have not been hedging the currency risk because of a perceived stability of the rupee.
The spot rupee has been stable at 35.70/85 to a dollar for the past one year.
Importers are not covering their forward dollar requirements in view of the stagnant dollar/rupee rate.
